ideas.qText: Do I have 5 syllables in my first line?
Do I have 7 syllables in my second line?
Do I have 5 syllables in my third line?
Does my haiku flow from a beginning to an end?

organization.qText: Does my haiku focus on something in nature?
Does my haiku make sense?

voice.qText: Will my words create a lasting picture in my reader’s mind? Check for powerful verbs, specific nouns, and creative descriptions. Revise as needed.

wordChoice.qText: Will my audience feel a connection to what I have written?

sentenceFluency.qText: Do my words and phrases add to the rhythm and style of my haiku?

conventions.qText: Do I place commas, if any, where I want my reader to pause?
Do I place end marks, if any, where I want my reader to end one thought?
Do I have correct capital letters?

ideas.qText: Do lines 1, 2, and 5 have 3 stressed beats?
Do lines 3 and 4 have 2 stressed beats?
Do lines 1, 2, and 5 rhyme?
Do lines 3 and 4 rhyme?
Does my limerick have a beginning that leads to a funny ending?

organization.qText: Does my limerick make sense, even though it may be silly?

voice.qText: Do my words create a funny picture in my reader's mind? Check for lively verbs, specific nouns, and creative descriptions. Revise as needed.

wordChoice.qText: Will my audience laugh at the silliness of my limerick?

sentenceFluency.qText: Do my words and phrases add to the rhythm and style of my limerick?

ideas.qText: Did I begin with a topic, followed by 2 describing words, 3 action words, 4 word phrase, 3 action words, 2 describing words, and end with a synonym for the topic?

ideas.qText: Did I type my street address or post office box?
Do I have a greeting such as Dear _____, followed by a comma?
Does my opening paragraph sound like the beginning of a conversation with the person I am writing to?
Does the order of my ideas make my letter easy to understand? To move text, highlight the text, select cut from the text editor tools, click where you want the text to go, and select paste.
Do I use transitions to connect my thoughts and keep my reader focused? Highlight transitions. Consider places where transitions are needed. Refer to Writing Tools - Transitions.
Do my ideas and details move along at a good pace? Do not spend too much time on one idea and not enough on another. Add or delete details as needed.
Does my final paragraph sound like I am ending a conversation and saying good-bye?
Do I close with a personal closing such as, Sincerely, Love, Best regards, or Your friend?

organization.qText: Do my ideas focus on what my reader will find interesting? Will my reader want to write me back? Delete unrelated, repeated, or uninteresting details.
Do I share specific experiences, information, or stories for my reader to imagine or experience? Add details as needed.
Is my letter easy to understand? Change or delete details that might confuse your reader.

voice.qText: Will some of my words or phrases make my reader want to remember what I have said?
Have I chosen words that are correct and appropriate for my reader and my purpose? Change or define words that might not be understood.

Does my letter sound natural? Avoid thesaurus overkill! When trying to vary words, try saying things in a different way rather than randomly selecting words from the thesaurus to plug into your writing.

Do I use specific nouns, lively verbs, and vivid descriptions to make my letter enjoyable to read? Revise general nouns and verbs. Add detailed descriptions where needed. Refer to Writing Tools - Show Don't Tell.
Do I avoid repeated words, unnecessary wordiness, or overused words? Change repeated or overused words. Revise wordiness. Refer to Writing Tools - Correcting Wordiness.

wordChoice.qText: Does my letter relate to my reader's age and reflect my relationship with this person? A letter to a friend might have a different tone than a letter to a grandparent. Refer to Writing Tools - Voice.
Does my letter meet the expectations of my audience and purpose?
Will my letter cause my reader to experience emotions such as feeling happy, sad, excited, or surprised? Think about what will make your reader feel something. Refer to Writing Tools - Voice.
Does my letter sound like me? Revise your letter if you did not write in a way that shows your unique personality.

sentenceFluency.qText: Do my sentence structures make my main ideas clear and show how my ideas connect? Revise sentences as needed to make ideas and details easy to understand. Refer to Writing Tools - Types of Sentence Structures.
Do I have short and long sentences to make my sentences flow like a natural conversation would? Read your letter aloud to hear the flow of your writing. Refer to Writing Tools - Combining Sentences.

Have I used a variety of sentence structures or patterns that make my writing easy to read aloud? To see if you have sentence variety, label your sentences simple (s), compound ( c ), complex (cx), and compound-complex (cc). Revise sentences as needed. Refer to Writing Tools - Types of Sentences.  Delete labels after revising.

Do I avoid beginning my sentences with the same word or pattern of words? Do not begin with and, but, or so. Try not to begin more than two sentences with the same word in the same paragraph. Refer to Writing Tools - Combining Sentences.
Do I avoid awkward, run-on sentences? Find where one thought ends and another begins. Refer to Writing Tools - Correcting Run-on or Rambling Sentences.

Do I avoid choppy or fragmented sentences unless they are used occasionally to add style? Combine choppy or fragmented sentences or add more details to a short sentence if needed. Refer to Writing Tools -Combine Sentences.
If I used dialogue to show what someone actually said, does it sound natural?

conventions.qText: Do I have correct capital letters and abbreviations? Refer to Writing Tools - Conventions.
Do I have correct end punctuation, commas, apostrophes, quotation marks, colons, semicolons, dashes, and parentheses? Refer to Writing Tools - Conventions.

Do I spell each word correctly? Click the spell check tool in the text editor to see any misspelled words. Correct any spellings that are identified. If it is not there, your teacher has turned it off for this assignment.
Have I checked carefully for missing words? Ex: We went the store. The word "to" is missing.
Are my sentences free of errors in grammar and usage? Check verb tenses, subject-verb agreement, degrees of comparison, and easily confused words and correct as needed.
Do I indent paragraphs five spaces and have correct spacing between words and sentences?

ideas.qText: Did I type my street address or post office box? Ex: 2680 Berkshire Parkway
Did I type my city, state, and zip? Ex: Des Moines, IA 50325
Did I type the current date? Ex: February 16, 2009
Did I type the receiver's name on one line? Ex: Mr. Charles Wittman
Did I type the receiver's street address or post office box on one line? Ex: 1000 N. 2nd Avenue
Did I type the city, state, and zip on one line? Ex: Logan, IA 51546

Does my final paragraph sound like I am completing a meeting with this person and a response would be appreciated? Add a concluding paragraph if needed.
Do I end my letter with a formal closing such as, Sincerely, followed by a comma?
Did I leave enough room to sign my name between the closing and my typed first and last name when I print the perfect copy?

ideas.qText: Does my introduction capture my reader's attention and create the desire to keep reading? Never begin with something like: This story is about…  Refer to Writing Tools - Introductions.
Will my reader have some idea of the main characters, setting, and conflict or problem after reading the opening of my story?
Do I arrange my events in chronlogical order, that is in the order they occur? If I use flashbacks, do make them easy to understand?
Do I clearly link each event to the events that happened before and the events that happen after?  Look for time and space connections. Add details as needed.

Do my events move along at a well-controlled pace, adding to the tension and building to the climax or high point of the story? Do not spend too much time on one event or description and not enough on another. Add or delete details as needed.
Do I use transitions to tie events together and show the passage of time? Highlight transitions and consider places where transitions are needed. Refer to Writing Tools - Transitions.
Do I use paragraph breaks to clearly separate the events and enhance meaning?
Do I build suspense with at least three events that the characters go through because of the problem?
Have I shown that my characters have made a discovery about life or have come to understand something?
Do I bring my story to a natural, surprising, or thought-provoking end? Never end with something like: The end or Now I have told you about… Refer to Writing Tools - Conclusions.
Is my title unique, original, and intriguing? Will it capture my audience's attention? Refer to Writing Tools - Writing Effective Titles.

Evaluate the Body

0 Do I present my arguments in the most effective order for this persuasive essay?
Evaluate Your Conclusion
1 Does my conclusion paragraph have 3 to 4 well-developed sentences? No new information is included.
2 Does my conclusion summarize the main points already made and restate the thesis forcefully?
3 Does my concluding sentence bring resolution and closure, and, if appropriate, offer new insight on the issue or urge the reader to take action?
Evaluate Your Title
4 Is my title unique, original, and intriguing? Does it capture the overall meaning of the writing?
5 If a title page is required, do I include all required information?
